LANG

RESIGNS STUDENT
COUNCIL POSITION AT
CLASS MEETING

Announced by Student
Council Head

John Lang, freshman delegate to
the Student Council, handed in his
resignation at a class meeting held
after last week's assembly. He explained that, after due consideration,
he had decided to take this step because of his recent trouble with the

Object of Rush Explained

DR. WIGHT SENIOR
' HONORARY PRESIDENT
Dr. Carol Van Buren Wight
was chosen honorary president
of the Senior Class at a meeting held last Thursday. This
is'Dr. Wight's second year as
Senior adviser, for last year's
graduating class likewise accorded him this honor.
The Seniors also confirmed
the fixing of their class dues
at $31.50 for the year.

Meet Tomorrow

SUPPRESSION OF BONFIRE
PERMIT EXPLAINED BY
CITY OFFICIAL
Commissioner Hough Addresses Full
Assembly Justifying Position;
Cheer Practice Held

Stating that a bonfire within the
city limits is dangerous and a menace to property, Commissioner
Hough of the city fire department
caused the audience at the weekly
assembly last Thursday to abandon
all idea of a fire.
While introducing Mr. Hough,
President Goodnow took occasion to
clarify his stand in regard to the St.
John's bonfire. Contrary to the rumor which was being circulated
about the campus,. Dr. Goodnow did
not issue an order prohibiting the
bonfire; such a move would have
been in direct conflict with the principles of student government. He
and Dr. Ames discussed the matter
with the Student Council, which applied to the fire department for a
permit, and failing, issued the fateful order.

Frosh-Soph athletic competition
will begin tomorrow when the rival
classes meet on the track at Homewood Field. Judging from the number of Freshmen and Sophornores
out for their respective teams, the
Frosh should have the advantage.
There are about fifteen Freshmen
out as compared to five,Sophomores.

JAYS RUN WILD OVER
ST. JOHN'S TEAM 34-0
Lawrence Individual Star As Flashy Hopkins
Eleven Rolls Up Five Touchdowns
GWINN WINS MIDDLE
STATES SIX MILE RUN
Dick Gwinn won the ninth
annual Middle Atlantic States
Collegiate Athletic Association's six mile run in Van
Courtlandt Park, New York
City, last Saturday, in the
time of 30 minutes 26 seconds. His nearest competitor, Boulton, of Alfred University, crossed the finish line
31 seconds behind him.
Gwinn was the Blue Jay's
only entry, and team honors
went to Alfred University.
The practice meet with the
Emorvwood Club will be held
this Saturday, the date having
been changed.
HOPKINS FROSH DOWNED
BY FOREST PARK BY
13-6 SCORE
Fumbles and Lack of Teamwork Are
Factors in Defeat

Frequent penalties coupled with
fumbles and lack of teamwork
proved the undoing of the Hopkins

Playing wide-awake football and
with all four backs driving and passing the ball through the St. John's
line, Johns Hopkins easily crushed
its traditional rival 34-0 last Saturday at Homewood, deadlocking the
ancient series that started in 1888 at
17-all.
Five touchdowns, a safety, and
two extra points gave Hopkins its
score. All were made in the last
three periods, and each touchdown
by a different man. Tom Biddison,
in the line-up for the first time since
the Loyola game, played a spectacular game in the line. It was he who
picked up a fumbled punt and
scored the first touchdown early in
the second quarter. This play
knocked the fight from St. John's
and spurred Hopkins on to two
more touchdowns before the end of
the half.
Lyons Receives kick-off

The game opened with Lyons receiving the St. John's kick-off and
running it back to his own 22-yard
line. The Jays started right off
,with a drive that netted three first
downs, Caplan and Lawrence doing
most of the gaining. At this point
the tide changed when Turner intercepted a forward pass in mid-field.
An exchange of kicks followed and
Zimmerman brought short-lived joy
to the St. John's rooters by racing
around and to the 10-yard line. On
the next play Mallonee recovered
Rosebarry's fumble and the threat
was staved off. The quarter ended
with the ball in midfield.
Dugan punted at the start of the
second period, Hopkins receiving
the ball on its 15-yard line. Lyons
returned the kick and as Dugan ran
after the bounding pigskin he
slipped and fell, barely touching the
ball with his fingertips. Biddison
grabbed it up and ran unmolested to
the first score. Mallonee made good
on the extra point.
St. John's seemed demoralized
and punted after receiving the kickoff. Lyons then unleashed a beautifully diversified running and aerial
attack that brought one first down
after another, ending in a heave to
Clayton over the goal line for the
second score. Mallonee's dropkick
was wide and the score was: Hopkins, 13; St. John's, 0.

R. W. GARIS PROMOTED TO
GRADE OF CAPTAIN
Memorial Exercises Held on Armistice
Day

Cadet First Lieutenant Robert W.
Garis, battalion adjutant of the local R. 0. T. C. unit, has been promoted to the grade of captain and
unit adjutant. Cans takes the place
of John G. Jory, who had been selected as unit adjutant, but who
failed to return to the university.
Other promotions made at the
same time were: Allan E. Vivell,
second lieutenant, to first lieutenant
and battalion adjutant to replace
Cans; and Sergeants Thomas E.
Biddison and Harry W. Warfield to
color sergeants. Frank W. Lands
was given the grade of second lieutenant.
Simple exercises were held Armistice Day in honor of Maryland
dead, on University Parkway.
There was a prayer by an army
chaplain and a wreath was laid on
the memorial. Then a picked firing
squad from the R. 0. T. C. fired
several volleys, and the bugler of
the unit sounded taps.

JAYS RUN WILD OVER
ST. JOHN'S TEAM 34-0
Lawrence Individual Star As Flashy Hopkins
Eleven Rolls Up Five Touchdowns
GWINN WINS MIDDLE
STATES SIX MILE RUN
Dick Gwinn won the ninth
annual Middle Atlantic States
Collegiate Athletic Association's six mile run in Van
Courtlandt Park, New York
City, last Saturday, in the
time of 30 minutes 26 seconds. His nearest competitor, Boulton, of Alfred University, crossed the finish line
31 seconds behind him.
Gwinn was the Blue Jay's
only entry, and team honors
went to Alfred University.
The practice meet with the
Emorvwood Club will be held
this Saturday, the date having
been changed.
HOPKINS FROSH DOWNED
BY FOREST PARK BY
13-6 SCORE
Fumbles and Lack of Teamwork Are
Factors in Defeat

Frequent penalties coupled with
fumbles and lack of teamwork
proved the undoing of the Hopkins

Playing wide-awake football and
with all four backs driving and passing the ball through the St. John's
line, Johns Hopkins easily crushed
its traditional rival 34-0 last Saturday at Homewood, deadlocking the
ancient series that started in 1888 at
17-all.
Five touchdowns, a safety, and
two extra points gave Hopkins its
score. All were made in the last
three periods, and each touchdown
by a different man. Tom Biddison,
in the line-up for the first time since
the Loyola game, played a spectacular game in the line. It was he who
picked up a fumbled punt and
scored the first touchdown early in
the second quarter. This play
knocked the fight from St. John's
and spurred Hopkins on to two
more touchdowns before the end of
the half.
Lyons Receives kick-off

The game opened with Lyons receiving the St. John's kick-off and
running it back to his own 22-yard
line. The Jays started right off
,with a drive that netted three first
downs, Caplan and Lawrence doing
most of the gaining. At this point
the tide changed when Turner intercepted a forward pass in mid-field.
An exchange of kicks followed and
Zimmerman brought short-lived joy
to the St. John's rooters by racing
around and to the 10-yard line. On
the next play Mallonee recovered
Rosebarry's fumble and the threat
was staved off. The quarter ended
with the ball in midfield.
Dugan punted at the start of the
second period, Hopkins receiving
the ball on its 15-yard line. Lyons
returned the kick and as Dugan ran
after the bounding pigskin he
slipped and fell, barely touching the
ball with his fingertips. Biddison
grabbed it up and ran unmolested to
the first score. Mallonee made good
on the extra point.
St. John's seemed demoralized
and punted after receiving the kickoff. Lyons then unleashed a beautifully diversified running and aerial
attack that brought one first down
after another, ending in a heave to
Clayton over the goal line for the
second score. Mallonee's dropkick
was wide and the score was: Hopkins, 13; St. John's, 0.

ALCAZAR

R. W. GARIS PROMOTED TO
GRADE OF CAPTAIN
Memorial Exercises Held on Armistice
Day

Cadet First Lieutenant Robert W.
Garis, battalion adjutant of the local R. 0. T. C. unit, has been promoted to the grade of captain and
unit adjutant. Cans takes the place
of John G. Jory, who had been selected as unit adjutant, but who
failed to return to the university.
Other promotions made at the
same time were: Allan E. Vivell,
second lieutenant, to first lieutenant
and battalion adjutant to replace
Cans; and Sergeants Thomas E.
Biddison and Harry W. Warfield to
color sergeants. Frank W. Lands
was given the grade of second lieutenant.
Simple exercises were held Armistice Day in honor of Maryland
dead, on University Parkway.
There was a prayer by an army
chaplain and a wreath was laid on
the memorial. Then a picked firing
squad from the R. 0. T. C. fired
several volleys, and the bugler of
the unit sounded taps.
